abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability is highly likely, and the
            institutional development impact is substantial.
            Nonetheless, lessons suggest that: 1) tax administration
            projects do include investments in automation, due to the
            nature of tax processing, but the strong inclination to
            focus on the complexities inherent in automation
            procurement, and implementation, due to a country's
            difficult environment to understand the business
            requirements, and the human resources dimension of change,
            may reverse project priorities, at the expense of the
            expected tax administration reforms, as was the case.
            Instead, supervision should include the right mix of
            professionals to stay focused on implementation priorities;
            2) following on automation investments, an information
            technology (IT) tactical plan, prepared early on, would have
            allowed an easier management of change, based on shared
            objectives, strategies, and performance indicators. The
            absence of such a plan, was the cause of unrealistic
            financial resource allocation, and project timetable. But,
            the process of change must be directed by professional tax
            administrators, not the IT department, who most likely would
            lack tax administration knowledge; 3) training programs
            should be monitored, to ensure the relevance of topics, and
            the adequacy of know-how; and, 4) unscrupulous practices may
            be prevented through stronger financial controls.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the project is to help
            strengthen tax administration, in line with the ongoing tax
            reform, in order to miximize tax revenues in a sustainable
            way.  The project is designed to support the Tax and
            Financial Controls Office's (APEH's) modernization
            efforts to develop and streamline policies and procedures,
            and to implement the underlying information technology
            systems necessary for the functioning of a modern and
            efficient tax administration.  Specifically, the project
            will support:  (a) institutional development through the
            financing of short-term experts to provide advice in tax
            administration; (b) development and implementation of a new
            information technology system, including (i) technical
            assistance; (ii) computers and peripheral equipment; (iii)
            software development tools; and (iv) administrative software
            packages; and (c) training in development and the use of
            applications systems.  Training in use of hardware, and
            software tools will be provided by suppliers.
